content.title: Learning to Infer Unseen Contexts in Causal Contextual Reinforcement Learning
content.TL;DR: We introduce a new task to evaluate reasoning capabilities of contextual agents, showing non-causal agents struggle to generalise in this task. We introduce a contextual attention module that helps agents discover causal factors & better generalise.
content.abstract: In Contextual Reinforcement Learning (CRL), a change in the context variable can cause a change in the distribution of the states. Hence contextual agents must be able to learn adaptive policies that can change when a context changes. Furthermore, in certain scenarios agents have to deal with unseen contexts, and be able to choose suitable actions. In order to generalise onto unseen contexts, agents need to not only detect and adapt to previously observed contexts, but also reason about how a context is constructed, and what are the causal factors of context variables. In this paper, we propose a new task and environment for Causal Contextual Reinforcement Learning (CCRL), where the  performance of different agents can be compared in a causal reasoning task. Furthermore, we introduce a Contextual Attention Module that allows the agent to test different interventions, and discover the causal factors. Finally, we demonstrate that non-causal agents fail to generalise onto unseen contexts, while the agents incorporating the proposed module can achieve better performance in unseen contexts.
